journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part A: Journal of Power and Energy

title-group.article-title: Incorporation of forward blade sweep in preliminary controlled vortex design of axial flow rotors

article-meta.aff: Department of Fluid Mechanics, Budapest University of Technology and Economics, Bertalan Lajos u. 4 – 6, H-1111 Budapest, Hungary.

abstract.p: A new controlled vortex design (CVD) method has been presented herein, incorporating forward blade sweep (FSW) in the preliminary design phase of axial flow rotors. Supplementing the traditional quasi-two-dimensional (Q2D) technique applied to CVD rotors of notable radial flow, the new method enables a more accurate consideration and control of blade aerodynamics along the three-dimensional suction side flow paths, where the majority of loss is generated away from the endwalls. For this purpose, the new method unifies Q2D and quasi-three-dimensional (Q3D) blade design approaches for CVD rotors. The incorporated Q2D and Q3D approaches can rely on traditional cascade correlations. The Q3D approach is to be aided by computational fluid dynamics. In contrast to the view dominating in literature that sweep is prescribed arbitrarily in preliminary design, the new method serves with the FSW angle distribution as design output. This means that the favourable blade stacking geometry is a result of the proposed preliminary design process. A design case study has been presented for demonstrating the consistency and advantages of the proposed method. At the design flow rate, fair agreement was found between the simulated and modelled three-dimensional flow features for the FSW rotor. Furthermore, moderation of total pressure loss was observed on the suction side away from the endwalls, leading to efficiency gain.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Controlled vortex design (CVD) is widely used for rotors of axial flow turbomachinery. CVD means that, in contrast to the classic free vortex design (FVD) concept prescribing spanwise constant design blade circulation, the circulation – and thus, the isentropic total pressure rise – increases along the dominant part of the blade span in a prescribed manner. As outlined in, e.g. Vad [1, 2], CVD offers several benefits, such as, among others, realization of high specific performance, moderation of hub losses and outlet loss, and basis for obtainment of simple and easy-to-manufacture rotor geometry.

As a consequence of spanwise changing circulation, the blade passage flow for a CVD rotor is characteristically 3D. Intense radial outward flow may develop on the suction side (SS) of the CVD blades, associated with the vortices shed from the trailing edge (TE). A blade is of forward sweep (FSW) if the sections of a straight datum blade are shifted parallel to their chord in such a way that a blade section under consideration is upstream of the neighbouring blade section at lower radius. It has been pointed out by the author that FSW is especially beneficial for the rotors of CVD, in terms of moderating the loss near the tip [1] as well as away from the endwalls [2].

In Vad [2], the literature survey implied that, away from the endwalls, most loss is generated in the blade SS boundary layer. Therefore, the control of loss generated along the near-SS flow paths is of primary interest in blade design. In the case study in the aforementioned reference, 3D flow paths on the SS of CVD rotors were investigated away from the endwalls. Conical surfaces approximately fitting these flow paths were considered. As a brief approximation, it was assumed that the elemental blade cascades fitting these conical surfaces can be developed into 2D cascade planes. Accordingly, the development of total pressure loss along the 3D SS flow paths was studied on the basis of a Q3D cascade approach, utilizing 2D cascade data [3]. It was found that the loss developing along the SS flow paths can be moderated by applying FSW, due to flow path shortening. The Q3D cascade approach was introduced as a tool for estimating the order of magnitude of the total pressure loss along the 3D rotor flow paths, as well as its reduction via flow path shortening due to FSW.

The aforementioned results serve as the basis for elaborating a new concept for incorporating FSW in preliminary CVD. The main features of the proposed new concept are listed below.
The proposed concept supplements the widespread Q2D approach that is used extensively in preliminary CVD. As noted in Pullan and Harvey [4] and Cumpsty [5], the early stages of blade design are still often done on a 2D basis. The Q2D approach is frequently applied even being aware that blade sweep and/or spanwise changing design blade circulation introduce 3D effects [6, 7]. As referred to in Pullan and Harvey [4], it is stated in the classic work of Smith and Yeh [6] that a 2D approach can be correctly employed for a plane perpendicular to the stacking axis of a swept blade. Recently, Pullan and Harvey [4] presented a simple method for estimating the change in blade boundary layer loss with sweep – in a 2D aerodynamic loss approach. In preliminary CVD, the Q2D approach has been used in the past decades, and is used even nowadays, occasionally regarding blades featuring sweep as well, e.g. references [8] to [16].
The concept combines the Q2D approach with a Q3D approach. In the Q3D approach, the elemental – conical – blade sections are designed as ones fitting the 3D SS streamlines. By such combination, the concept provides a design tool enabling loss moderation along the 3D SS flow paths, by means of ‘favourable’ blade geometry, while simultaneously retaining the main features of the Q2D approach.
The concept relies on traditional 2D cascade measurement data, e.g. references [3], [8], and [17]. Classic empirical 2D cascade correlations are used even very recently in preliminary blade design, e.g. Templalexis et al. [18] and Rossetti et al. [19]. Correlations by Howell are of frequent use, e.g. references [8], [15], [19] to [21]. As a representative choice, empirical correlations by Howell are used in this article. However, this choice means no restriction in using the concept incorporating other empirical databases.
A key issue in the concept is determining the favourable blade solidity, separately in the Q2D and Q3D approaches. Correlations by Howell et al. [17], cited in Carter [8], provide a convenient tool for this purpose. Howell’s data are used to this day for obtainment of favourable solidity [19]. It is noted, however, that the favourable solidity can be estimated using other databases as well, as demonstrated in Vad [2] and Carter [8].
At a given mean radius of a rotor of CVD, the favourable solidity has been found to be lower in the Q3D approach than that in the Q2D approach. FSW offers a unique means for simultaneous realization of such different favourable solidities in one blade geometry. Accordingly, FSW is quantified in the concept as being favourable for a rotor of CVD. The corresponding sweep angle distribution is therefore an output, i.e. an explicit result, of the proposed preliminary CVD process. This provides a new design feature in comparison to the literature. In contrast to the concept presented herein, reports on axial flow rotors of CVD usually consider sweep as a design input, i.e. a feature prescribed by the designer. A favourable stacking line geometry is then sought by means of testing various CVD rotors of blade sweep prescribed in an arbitrary manner, as in references [10], [12], and [22] to [27].
In these days, use of computational fluid dynamics (CFD) already at early stages of blade design is solicited for aircraft engine fans [5] as well as for industrial fans [28]. For brief estimation of the 3D SS flow paths, forming the basis of the Q3D approach presented herein, CFD is applied to the preliminary blade geometry.
The concept serves for the preliminary design of blade geometry only away from the endwalls – where the Q2D and Q3D approaches are presumed to be applicable [4, 5]. In addition to FSW, incorporation of dihedral (lean) in blade stacking is also discussed in this article. The final blade geometry, optionally including both sweep and dihedral, can be obtained via refinements using fully 3D, CFD-based methods, as proposed, e.g. in Cumpsty [5] and Ramakrishna and Govardhan [27]. In the near-endwall region, 3D considerations are to be made in the final design. For example, near the hub, not FSW but backward sweep – corresponding to positive sweep – is found to be beneficial [7]. However, such refinements are beyond the scope of the preliminary design method proposed in this article.
The discussion in this article (a) will regard CVD rotors of relatively large spanwise gradient of blade circulation, exhibiting pronounced radial outward flow on the SS; (b) will be confined to axial flow rotors of enthalpy-increasing, gas-handling turbomachinery; (c) will consider an isolated rotor (rotor-only configuration), or a rotor without an inlet guide vane but followed by an outlet guide vane stator – accordingly, swirl-free inflow will be considered; and (d) will presume incompressible flow.

The 2D cascade concept, as well as Q2D and Q3D approaches of rotor flow, is outlined first. Then, descriptive relationships for rotor flows are discussed, in comparison between the Q2D and Q3D approaches. The preliminary blade design procedure is outlined, with the innovative incorporation of FSW. Finally, a design case study is presented, supporting the appropriateness of the proposed concept. A preliminary version of the design concept proposed by the author was published, e.g. in Vad [29] and Corsini et al. [30].

sec.title: 2.1 2D cascade concept
sec.p: In this section, the chosen empirical 2D cascade correlation, as well as its physical relevance to the proposed design concept, is presented.

As noted earlier, a key issue of the proposed design concept is determining the favourable blade solidity which can be determined either directly from Howell’s 2D cascade correlations (Howell et al. [17], cited in Carter [8]), or indirectly, using other cascade databases [2, 8], as a function of inlet and outlet flow angles. In the process of obtaining the favourable solidity, the blade section lift coefficient is incorporated herein as auxiliary data, for lifelike interpretation of the blade load. Classic lift coefficients are used even nowadays as lifelike approximate indicators of blade aerodynamics [4, 11, 14, 15, 18, 21, 31–33].

Combining the expression for the blade circulation as a function of blade spacing and pitchwise velocity change, Bernoulli equation, Kutta–Joukowski theorem, and definition of lift coefficient CL=(dFL/dr)/(cρv∧∞ 2/2) [11], leads to the following statement. The isentropic static pressure rise through a 2D cascade is directly proportional to the product of blade solidity and lift coefficient; for fixed density, mean flow velocity, and mean flow angle (1)

Dividing equation (1) by the chord length c implies (Δpis/c) ∼ CL for fixed blade spacing, density, and mean flow characteristics. By such means, it is demonstrated that CL is a lifelike indicator of the chordwise mean adverse pressure gradient, approximated as (Δpis/c).

Let us consider a series of consecutive blades of number Nb, having a fixed pitchwise extension sbNb. The solidity in equation (1) can be written as c/sb = (cNb)/(sbNb), where cNb approximates the sum of ‘blade wetted length’ [2] through the blade series. If Δpis is prescribed, equation (1) indicates the following trends.
Increasing CL tends to increase the adverse pressure gradient but tends to decrease the blade wetted length cNb – the latter moderates the effect of skin friction.
In contrast, decreasing CL tends to decrease the adverse pressure gradient but tends to increase the blade wetted length – the latter increases the effect of skin friction.
The above implies the existence of a favourable solidity (c/sb)*, associated with a favourable lift coefficient CL *, for minimizing the total pressure loss [2].

In what follows, an approximate correlation, enabling a simple mathematical treatment, is sought for CL *. Let us assume that a prescribed Δpis in equation (1) is obtained at a CL * value. Then, the isentropic static pressure rise is intended to be increased by increasing the solidity: ∂(Δpis)/∂(c/sb) > 0. According to the chain rule (2)

Increasing the solidity tends to increase the interference of the adjoining blades on the flow around a blade, and thus, tends to reduce the lift coefficient, e.g. Lakshminarayana [11]. Therefore, ∂CL */∂(c/sb)<0 is presumed. This implies via relationship (2) that ∂(Δpis)/∂CL *<0: increasing the static pressure rise tends to lessen CL *. This statement is in accordance with Carter [8] remarking that the greater the static pressure rise, the smaller is the permissible CL. The isentropic static pressure rise can be expressed using the Bernoulli equation as follows. (3)

The result ∂(Δpis)/∂CL *<0, together with equation (3), allows for the following approximation: CL * increases monotonously with (cosα1/cosα2)2. Introducing a generalized power exponent BCL > 0 instead of the value of 2 in equation (3), and taking direct proportionality, using a factor ACL > 0, as the simplest mathematical approach, CL * is approximated herein using the following formula (4)

This approximation is consistent with the empirical cascade correlation reported in Howell et al. [17], and referred to in Carter [8] – termed herein as Howell’s correlation, – with the cascade correlations by Carter [8], and with Lieblein [3]. For the Howell’s correlation, ACL = 2 and BCL = 2.75 are specified in Carter [8], for the solidity range (c/sb) of 0.6–2.

The relationship in equation (4) manifests herein the adaptation of experimental 2D cascade data to rotor flow. For rotor Q2D as well as Q3D approaches, the favourable solidity is approximated in this article via CL * with use of formula (4), in which, however, the flow angles are calculated not with absolute but with relative velocities.

sec.title: 2.2 Q2D rotor flow approach
sec.p:
As discussed in Vad [1, 2], significant radial velocities may develop in a CVD rotor. However, in the Q2D CVD rotor approach, the radial flow is neglected. Fictitious stream tubes of constant middle radius r12 – termed herein as cylindrical stream tubes – are assumed through the rotor along the z-axis, as illustrated in Figure 1. It is assumed in the Q2D approach that the elemental annular cascade enclosed in a cylindrical stream tube can be developed into a 2D cascade plane. Accordingly, the preliminary Q2D blade design relies on a 2D experimental database. Further details on the application of Q2D approach in preliminary CVD are published in references [8] to [15]. Fig. 1
Comparative sketches on Q2D and Q3D approaches

sec.title: 2.3 Q3D rotor flow approach
sec.p: A comprehensive overview on Q3D – axisymmetric – design approaches is given in Lakshminarayana [11]. In the Q3D approach used herein, the elemental blade cascade under consideration is enclosed between neighbouring conical surfaces of mean cone half-angle β, as shown in Fig. 1. The elemental conical cascade is characterized by radii r1 and r2 at the blade leading edge (LE) and TE, respectively. Since the Q3D blade design approach is intended herein to control the loss generated along the SS flow paths, the β values are to be set by such means that the conical surfaces approximately fit the SS limiting streamlines.

The tangent of local yaw angle of the limiting streamlines, εL, is defined as follows (conf. Cooke [34]) (5) in which the relative velocity is decomposed into two components: wr is the radial velocity component and wcyl the component of the relative velocity fitting the cylindrical surface in the SS point under consideration. As n → 0, the suction surface – onto which the limiting streamline fits – is reached. The representative mean ɛ~L value along an SS streamline under consideration is predicted on the basis of CFD (e.g. Corsini and Rispoli [35]).

Figure 1 indicates the β half-angle of the cone of best fit to the SS limiting streamline of ɛ~L located at radius r12 at mid-chord (Q3D rotor approach). Such limiting streamline, extending from the LE to the TE, has a radial extension of r2 − r1 and has an approximate extension of c along the cylindrical surface of r12. Therefore, it can be written that (5a)

Figure 1 illustrates that the meridional projection of the chord, i.e. c·cosγ (r12), plays a role when calculating the tangent of β (5b) where γ (r12) is the stagger angle at mean radius r12 = (r1 + r2)/2. Combining equations (5a) and (5b) leads to a relationship for the calculation of β on the basis of ɛ~L predicted using CFD (6a)
In what follows, the radial velocity over the suction surface is approximated as follows (conf. Fig. 1) (6b)

Despite the presence of 3D flow, the adaptability of the 2D concept is assumed in the Q3D approach, as well as it was accepted in the Q2D approach [8–15]. Thus, it is assumed in the Q3D approach that the elemental conical cascade can be developed into a 2D cascade plane and can therefore be designed using a 2D database. This assumption is supported by the case study in Vad [2].

sec.title: 3.1 Relationships describing rotor flows
sec.p: Let us consider Q2D (cylindrical) and Q3D (conical) elemental cascades of equal mean radius r12 within the same rotor (Fig. 1). The favourable solidities will be approximated for both of them on the basis of 2D cascade data. Characteristics in the Q3D and Q2D approaches will be denoted with subscripts for a clear distinction.

The same functions will be used for both approaches for describing the radial distributions of v∧u2 and v∧z2. r12 is equal, but the inlet and outlet radii, r1 and r2, are different for the two approaches. Accordingly, v∧z2(r2), v∧z12(r12), and v∧u2(r2) are also different for cylindrical and conical elemental cascades of equal r12.

sec.title: 3.1.1 Relationships valid in both Q2D and Q3D approaches
sec.p: As suggested by e.g. Lakshminarayana [11], the axial velocity through an elemental cascade is represented by an inlet-to-outlet arithmetic mean value, i.e. (7a)
As an approximation for the fulfilment of conservation of mass through the elemental cascade, the following approximation is taken into account (7b)

The z-wise component of the angular momentum equation applied in the absolute frame of reference, to the control volume enclosing the elemental cascade (both Q2D and Q3D approaches, see Fig. 1), takes the following approximate form (conf. e.g. Lakshminarayana [11], Carolus [14]), considering equation (7b). (8)
Equation (8) can be expressed also in the relative frame of reference as (8a)

In equation (8a), the first integral, dMzAE, relates to the aerodynamic interaction of the blades with the relative flow via flow turning (conf. Lakshminarayana [11]) and the second integral, dMzCOR, represents the momentum of the Coriolis force field (2vrω is the tangential component of Coriolis field intensity). In axial flow rotors of CVD, not only local but also pitchwise-averaged radial velocities may be significant in the blade passages, and therefore, the Coriolis effect may be of importance. Still, to be consistent with the 2D cascade databases disregarding Coriolis forces, the Coriolis forces acting on rotor flow are arbitrarily neglected in the widespread Q2D rotor approach applied in preliminary CVD of axial flow rotors [8–15]. This implies that the torque reacting on any elemental rotor cascade is expressed solely as a consequence of aerodynamic interaction of the blades with the relative flow. Such neglect of Coriolis effect applies for any elemental cascade from hub to tip.

Taking the Q2D approach as a generally accepted preliminary design basis, the arbitrary neglect of Coriolis forces acting on the flow field in the axial rotor is generally applied herein. Therefore, equations (8) and (8a) are combined in the following approximation (8b)

The spanwise distribution of outlet axial velocity appearing in equation (8) is approximated with numerical integration of the simplified radial equilibrium equation, the use of which is suggested by references [11], [14], and [20] for general whirl distribution, i.e. including CVD. The non-dimensional form of simplified radial equilibrium equation enables a simple representation (9)

In the above equation, the outlet swirl coefficient ψ∧2 represents the isentropic total pressure rise, on the basis of the Euler equation of turbomachines, in the case of swirl-free inlet, in dimensionless form:
In equation (9), the kinetic energy related to the outlet radial velocity has been neglected in comparison to those related to the other outlet velocity components. Furthermore, the local total efficiency ηt [33] is taken herein as constant along the span. This simplifying assumption, suggested in Carolus [14], and supported by references [12], [32], [33], [36], is reasonable in the region away from the endwalls, to which the approach presented herein is anyway restricted.

Various styles for prescribing the radial distribution of the isentropic total pressure rise, manifested by ψ∧2(R2) and incorporated in equation (9), being a main feature of the CVD concept, are summarized, e.g. in Lakshminarayana [11] and Carolus [14]. The power function ψ∧2(R2) distribution [9, 35, 37] given in the following equation is taken herein as example. This choice means there is no restriction to introducing other ψ∧2(R2) distributions in the presented concept. (10)

sec.title: 3.1.2 Relationships valid for the Q3D approach
sec.p: The flow angles are obtained using the following equations, which consider that the meridional mean velocity is approximated as v∧z12/cosβ (Fig. 1). (11a) (11b)
The free-stream relative velocity is as follows (12)

In the above equation, the square of the meridional velocity component has been characterized by v∧z 12 Q3D 2(1+tan2β). Furthermore, the arithmetic mean value for the relative inlet and outlet tangential velocities – of r1Q3Dω and r2 Q3Dω-v∧u 2 Q3D, respectively – has been taken into account.
The free-stream flow angle is calculated as (13)

The lift coefficient CLQ3D is defined on the basis of the blade lift force, (dFL)Q3D, being perpendicular to the w∞Q3D vector, and being tangential to the conical surface. As an approximation, (dFL)Q3D manifests the effect of the aerodynamic interaction of the blade with the relative flow. Such approximation is supported (e.g.) by Carolus [14] and Lakshminarayana [38]. (14)

The term cQ3D dr12 cosβ in the denominator is the surface of an elemental blade section between the conical surfaces of half-angle β and radial distance dr12 (conf. Fig. 1); cQ3D is the ‘effective chord length’ fitting the cone of half-angle β.

The elemental z-wise torque reacting on the elemental cascade, dMz Q3D, included in equations (8), (8a), and (8b), can be expressed in another way as follows (conf. upper part of Fig. 1), considering r12 as lever arm for the blade force (15)

Combining equations (8) and (15), considering equations (7b), (13), and (14), and substitution of mean blade spacing sb12 = 2r12π/Nb gives the ‘fundamental cascade equation’ of the elemental cascade (conf. Carolus [14] and Lakshminarayana [38]) (16)

sec.title: 3.1.3 Relationships valid for the Q2D approach
sec.p: Substituting r1 = r2 = r12 and β = 0 into equations (11) to (16), and taking v∧z2(r12), v∧z12(r12)=[v∧z1(r12)+v∧z2(r12)]/2, and v∧u2(r12), instead of v∧z2(r2), v∧z12(r12)=[v∧z1(r1)+v∧z2(r2)]/2, and v∧u2(r2), respectively, formulae well known in axial fan design based on the Q2D approach (e.g. fundamental cascade equation in Carolus [14]) are obtained. The quantities related to the Q2D approach are subscripted accordingly, instead of using subscript ‘Q3D’.

sec.title: 3.2 Preliminary CVD procedure
sec.p:
The flow chart in Fig. 2 illustrates the main steps of the preliminary design process taken as example in this article, for an elemental rotor of radius R12. The chart contains quantities in dimensionless form for simplicity. The sequence of the tracks in the flow chart is referenced by Roman numerals. Fig. 2
Flow chart summarizing the main preliminary design steps for an elemental rotor

sec.title: 3.2.1 Design based on the Q2D approach
sec.p:
For correction, the design process may return from a given step to a previous one, within an iterative procedure. 1(a) Global performance values of Φ, Ψ, η¯t [33], as well as νht are taken as initial input data. 1(b) An inlet condition ϕ∧1(R1), being in accordance with Φ, and representing a dimensionless v∧z1(r1) distribution, is prescribed. 1(c) An initial ψ∧2(R2) distribution, representing a dimensionless v∧u2(r2) distribution, is prescribed, e.g. on the basis of equation (10). 1(d) An initial ϕ∧2(R2) distribution, representing a dimensionless v∧z2(r2) distribution, is calculated on the basis of equation (9), for which a ηt value being representative away from the endwalls is preliminarily chosen. 1(e) The ψ∧2(R2) and ϕ∧2(R2) distributions are iteratively refined, in order to match with the integral conditions represented by Φ, Ψ, and η¯t (conf. Carolus [14]), as well as to control the diffusion through the blading. The ϕ∧2(R2) distribution can be corrected for endwall blockage consideration. An empirical method for predicting blockage in CVD rotors is published in Vad [1]. Steps 1(a) to 1(e) are indicated in Fig. 2 by the block ‘Data input, preliminary calculation’.
1(f). The imaginary rotor is subdivided into Q2D elemental cascades along the span. Each elemental cascade under consideration has a mean radius r12. For each elemental cascade, the following characteristics are calculated in steps 1(g) to 1(i), with consideration of r1 = r2 = r12, and β = 0 (corresponding to the Q2D approach):
1(g). Term v∧z12 Q2D, based on equation (7a); w∞ Q2D, based on equation (12), and CL Q2D *·(c/sb 12)Q2D *, based on equation (16).
1(h). Terms α1 Q2D and α2 Q2D are calculated on the basis of equations (11a) and (11b). CL Q2D * is estimated using 2D cascade correlations, e.g. Howell’s correlation represented by equation (4).
1(i). Dividing CL Q2D *·(c/sb 12)Q2D *, obtained in step 1(g), by CL Q2D *, obtained in step 1(h), results in the favourable solidity (c/sb 12)Q2D * for the elemental cascade under consideration. The solidity can be expressed as c/sb12 = cNb/(2r12π). Therefore, calculating the favourable solidity controls cNb, related to the SS flow path length summed for all the blades of number Nb. By selecting an appropriate Nb value, and with knowledge of r12, the blade spacing sb12 is calculated, and the favourable chord length assigned to the elemental cylindrical cascade, cQ2D *, is obtained.
1(j). The camber geometry as well as the stagger angle γ (r12) are designed in order to match the designed performance at moderate losses. Appropriate ways of cambering and staggering are beyond the scope of this article.
Steps 1(g) to 1(j) are summarized in the block ‘Blade section calculation’, located in the ‘Q2D approach’ track, in Fig. 2.

sec.title: 3.2.2 Design based on the Q3D approach
sec.p:
Besides the Q2D approach, the blade characteristics of the same rotor can be obtained via a Q3D-based process as well.
2(a). The flow field in the rotor designed with the Q2D approach is to be tested using CFD. The distribution of mean yaw angle ɛ~L along the radius is estimated. See Section 2.3 for details.
2(b). With knowledge of the designed Q2D geometry incorporating the stagger angle γ (r12), the spanwise distribution of cone half-angle β for the Q3D approach is estimated along the span, using equation (6a).
2(c). Radii r1 and r2 are estimated for the cones using equation (5b), with knowledge of the formerly determined β, c, and γ data, and considering that r12 − r1 = r2 − r12.
2(d). The spanwise ϕ∧1, ϕ∧2 and ψ∧2 distributions established in Q2D design are used as the basis also for the Q3D approach. (For realization of these distributions also in the Q3D approach, and for further improvement of efficiency, re-cambering and re-staggering [7] techniques may iteratively be used.) For calculation of the individual Q3D elemental rotors, the ψ∧2 and ϕ∧2 distributions are used for determining the ϕ∧1(R1), ϕ∧2(R2), and ψ∧2(R2) data at the formerly estimated R1 and R2 radii.
Steps 2(a) to 2(d) are summarized in Fig. 2 in the block ‘Rotor CFD and evaluation’ located after label ‘III’.
2(e). Steps from 1(g) can be carried out in the Q3D approach, for the same elemental rotors of radii r12: v∧z12 Q3D (equation (7a)), CL Q3D *·(c/sb 12)Q3D * (equation (16)), α1 Q3D (equation (11a)), α2 Q3D (equation (11b)), CL Q3D * (equation (4)), (c/sb 12)Q3D *, and cQ3D *, are calculated. (See the block ‘Blade section calculation’, located in the ‘Q3D approach’ track, in Fig. 2.)
A possible way of further development of the Q3D method is the application of conformal transformation [11].

sec.title: 4 INCORPORATION OF FSW INTO PRELIMINARY CVD
sec.p:
The underlying physics of the proposed concept is explained qualitatively as follows, in a substantially simplified manner. Figure 3 compares the trends of the isobars on the SS of rotor blades of FVD and CVD. For simplicity in comparison, the meridional views of the blades are presented as coincident rectangles. Furthermore, the isobars for the FVD blade are simplified as straight lines being parallel to the view of the LE and TE. The darker the greyscale, the higher the pressure. The white zone represents the zone of minimum pressure, i.e. of maximum depression, incorporating the suction peak of the elemental blade sections. Let us assume identical static pressure distribution for the two blades at r12, i.e. the isobars intersect identically with the cylindrical surface of r12. In the case of the FVD blade, and also for the CVD blade in the Q2D approach, the radial flow is neglected, i.e. the fluid particles travel along the line of constant r ≡ r12 radial coordinate – labelled as ‘Q2D’ for the CVD blade. Fig. 3
Sketch for explaining the trends related to SS static pressure

In the case of the CVD blade, the spanwise increasing blade circulation, i.e. spanwise increasing lift, results in the following phenomena, in comparison to the FVD blade. (1) Reduced and increased depression is set up at radii below and above r12, respectively. Accordingly, the zone of maximum depression narrows and widens below and above r12, respectively, in Fig. 3. As a consequence, the isobars downstream of the suction peak (deceleration zone) tend to incline toward the LE and the TE below and above r12, respectively. (2) The aforementioned effect represents a negative radial pressure gradient in addition to the FVD case, over a significant portion of the chord. (3) This negative radial pressure gradient initiates radially outward flow. This is a simplified qualitative explanation why radially outward flow is generated on the SS of a blade of CVD. Due to radially outward flow, the flow path is inclined with the r ≡ r12 line. This path, passing the r ≡ r12 line at mid-chord, and being represented by the limiting streamline discussed formerly (to be modelled using CFD), is used in the Q3D approach. It is labelled as ‘Q3D’ in the figure. (4) Farther downstream of the suction peak, i.e. closer to the TE, the static pressure increases along the radius more intensely for the CVD blade than for the FVD one, according to the spanwise increasing pressure rise demanded in the CVD concept. Accordingly, the isobars closer to the TE tend to incline toward the TE and the LE below and above r12, respectively. Fig. 4
Sketch for obtaining favourable FSW angle: (a) the blade is viewed from the direction normal to the blade surface, in the absence of dihedral; (b) enlarged view of the grey triangle and its surroundings in (a); and (c) the blade is viewed from the direction parallel to the Q2D chordline at r12, in the presence of dihedral

The intersection of the ‘Q2D’ and ‘Q3D’ lines with the isobars in the decelerating regime quantifies the magnitude of streamwise adverse pressure gradient. Figure 3 suggests the following trend. In the case of the ‘Q3D’ line, the distance between the consecutive intersection points tends to be longer than that in the ‘Q2D’ case, farther away from the TE. This represents a reduced adverse pressure gradient. The trend is just the opposite closer to the TE. If the aforementioned trend of moderation of adverse pressure gradient dominates along the ‘Q3D’ line, this corresponds to a moderate averaged diffusion (deceleration), and thus, to a larger permissible CL *, in the Q3D approach.

Test calculations outlined in the previous section were carried out using parameters valid in ordinary fan applications. As a support to the above outlined qualitative explanation, it has been found indeed that, for the same mean radius r12, the diffusion (deceleration) is usually moderate in the Q3D approach, in comparison to that in the Q2D one, i.e. (17a)

The validity of this relationship is justified in Appendix 2. On the basis of equations (11a) and (11b), it can be pointed out that cosα is the ratio between the meridional velocity component and the relative velocity. By assuming approximately equal meridional velocities for the inlet and the outlet (see the aforementioned equations), relationship (17a) can be written as (17b)
Taking equation (4) into account, the above relationship implies (17c)

The fundamental cascade equations (conf. equation (16)) developed for the Q3D and Q2D approaches have been compared. For Q2D, see the comments in Section 3.1.3. The inequality expressed in relationship (17c) has been found to be dominant in the difference between the Q3D and Q2D fundamental cascade equations. This implies that the favourable solidity for the Q3D approach tends to be less than that for the Q2D one (17d)

By means of simultaneous realization of the different cQ2D * and cQ3D *<cQ2D * values for the same mean radius r12, in one blade geometry, the following goals are to be achieved: (1) The generally accepted traditional Q2D approach is incorporated via cQ2D *. (2) In addition, the loss generation along the SS is considered in the Q3D approach in a more realistic manner and is intended to be moderated via a permissible shortening of flow path: cQ3D *<cQ2D *. FSW offers a unique means for simultaneous incorporation of cQ2D * and cQ3D * in one blade geometry. Figure 4 gives an aid to the explanation. In Fig. 4(a), the blade is viewed from the direction normal to the FSW blade, being approximately normal to ur. The favourable FSW angle is approximated as follows, using Fig. 4(b)) (18)

The absolute value is taken in equation (18) for λ*, because, according to the sign convention in Smith and Yeh [6], the sweep angle is negative for FSW. The auxiliary angle λ′ is obtained in the following way. Applying the law of sines to the triangle next to the grey one in Fig. 4(b)) reads (19)

The expression under the square root multiplied by ½ is the length of the shortest side of the grey triangle. Rearrangement of equation (19) reads (20) where CR=cQ3D */cQ2D * is the Q3D-to-Q2D chord ratio.

It is conceivable using Fig. 4(b) that ɛ~L → 0 (no radial flow) implies CR → 1, λ′ → 0, and |λ*| → 0. Therefore, away from the endwalls, radial blade stacking is proposed by the presented design method for truly 2D rotor flows, approximated by the FVD style.

On the basis of an appropriate CFD tool, an iterative design procedure can be elaborated (Fig. 2). In the first step, an unswept (USW) rotor is designed using the Q2D approach (steps 1(a) to 1(j) in Section 3.2.1). The USW rotor is simulated, according to step 2(a) in Section 3.2.2. The first approximation of ɛ~L along the radius is made on this basis. Then, a first version of the FSW rotor is designed, on the basis of steps 2(b) to 2(e) in Section 3.2.2., and equations (18) and (20). This first version of the FSW rotor, labelled as FSW1, is surveyed by CFD. Given that FSW in itself moderates the radially outward SS flow in the case of rotors of CVD, e.g. references [1], [2], [23], and [35], a reduction is foreseen in ɛ~L for the FSW1 rotor, compared to the USW one. Using the reduced ɛ~L data, a next, FSW2 rotor version can be designed, for which equation (18) tailors a moderated |λ*| value. The CFD and redesign procedures can be repeated upon demand, for monitoring ɛ~i in the consecutive rotor versions FSWi. Fast convergence in |λ*| is foreseen via a few iterative steps. In addition to obtaining |λ*|, the profitability of using CFD at this preliminary design stage can be improved by simultaneously exploiting the CFD results in approximate diagnostics and treatment of other effects as well (conf. Cumpsty [5]), such as near-wall phenomena.

The Q3D chordline of cQ3D * is indicated in Fig. 4(a) as an inclined solid line. The axis of the ‘eye symbol’ in Fig. 4(a) illustrates the viewing direction being parallel to the Q2D chordline, i.e. this axis fits the LE and the TE at r12. Viewing the blade from this direction, the projection of the Q3D chordline of cQ3D * appears as indicated in Fig. 4(c) using a solid line segment. When applying dihedral of local angle κ, e.g. in circumferential forward skew [7], the blade surface in Fig. 4(a) – being approximately parallel to the Q3D chordline – can be viewed as making an angle κ with the ur direction, as illustrated in Fig. 4(c). Consequently, only the cQ3D *cosκ component of the Q3D favourable chord will play a role in determining λ*. Therefore, CR·cosκ is to be substituted into equation (20), instead of CR. In circumferential forward skew, the sweep and dihedral angles are in a relationship. Therefore, besides favourable FSW, equation (18) implies the existence of a favourable forward-skewed geometry as well. The ɛ~L distribution affected by both sweep and dihedral is to be monitored via the iterative CFD campaign.

Determining further blade geometrical details not discussed in this article must follow the usual guidelines of preliminary design. The style of profile as well as camber line geometry and the applied cascade database are to be in correspondence. Carter [8] suggests the following example, being relevant to industrial fans of easy-to-manufacture geometry. When Howell’s cascade correlation of equation (4) is chosen, a C4 profile – or, as an alternative, a profile of constant thickness, rounded at the LE and TE – can be applied to a circular-arc camber line.

The stagger and camber angles of the Q2D as well as Q3D blade sections are to be determined using the incidence and deviation rules corresponding to the cascade database. As a preliminary design approximation, the γ stagger angle of the FSW rotor at radius r12 can be obtained as the arithmetic mean of (a) the stagger angle resulting from the Q2D design approach at r12 and (b) the stagger angle of projection of the designed Q3D blade section at r12 to the cylindrical surface of r12 radius. Similar averaging process applies for obtaining the θ camber angle at r12. In the fully 3D, CFD-based refinements following the preliminary design, re-staggering and re-cambering techniques can be applied for correction of the swept blade, in order to retain the prescribed global total pressure rise [7].

sec.title: 5 DESIGN CASE STUDY
sec.p: An USW industrial fan rotor of high specific performance was designed using a Q2D approach by Bencze and was investigated by experimental means [37] (in Vad and Bencze [37], the USW rotor is labelled as BUP-29). The USW rotor was redesigned by the author using the method outlined in this article, resulting in a FSW, sweep-only (no dihedral) rotor. The redesign process carried out by the author was supported by CFD means due to Corsini et al. [39] and Corsini and Rispoli [41]. The FSW rotor designed by the author was compared to the USW rotor by Corsini and Rispoli [35].

In the design, the isentropic total pressure rise was prescribed along the span using the power function in equation (10), with m = 1.4. A uniform axial design inlet condition was assumed. The endwall blockage was considered by correcting the design outlet axial velocity profile, using the empirical correlation in Vad [1]. Howell’s correlation (equation (4)) was used in determining the favourable chord lengths in the Q2D and Q3D approaches. The solidity and the camber geometry were eventually corrected for manufacturing reasons.

Representative operational and geometrical data for the rotors are specified in Table 1. Possible discrepancies between the USW and FSW data are indicated as uncertainty ranges in the last column of the table. The rotor blades are of circular-arc camber line with a thin profile of uniform thickness [35] and of rounded LE and TE. The rotors were manufactured with tip diameter 630 mm and were run at 1100 r/min during the tests. Further details on the blade geometry at hub and tip are available in, e.g. Corsini and Rispoli [35]. Since this article focuses on the design point, the measured characteristic and efficiency curves are not included here but are available in references [35], [40], and [41]. Table 1
Rotor operational and geometrical data
Nb 12
νht 0.676
γmid (°) 47.4 ±0.4
θmid (°) 24.3 ±1.1
(c/sb)mid 1.235 ±0.005
AR 0.597
ΦD 0.5
ΨD 0.5
Mamid 0.103
Remid 4.01·105
ϕ∧1 mid 0.495
ϕ∧2 mid 0.530 ±0.010
ϕ∧12 mid 0.513 ±0.005
ψ∧2 mid 0.630 ±0.020
α1mid (°) 58.5 ±0.2
α2mid (°) 42.0 ±0.5

When designing FSW, the β distribution along the span, representing the Q3D approach, has iteratively been modelled on the basis of CFD. The spanwise distributions of designed, CFD, and laser Doppler anemometer (LDA) measured ψ∧2 and ϕ∧2 data are presented in Figure 5. The uncertainty of the LDA data, valid at 95 per cent level of confidence, is reported in Table 2, and is indicated by error bars in the diagrams. The fair agreement among the CFD [30, 35], experimental [37], and preliminary design data away from the endwalls supports the validity of the applied CFD technique as well as the reasonability of the swirl and axial velocity distributions applied in the design. Only limited efforts were made in the presented case study to correct the blade geometries to better match the designed ψ∧2 and ϕ∧2 distributions. Fig. 5
Spanwise distributions of ϕ∧2 and ψ∧2 Table 2
Experimental uncertainty
Quantity Φ Ψ ψ∧2 ϕ∧2
Uncertainty ±1.5% ±0.5% ±4% ±1.5%

Figure 6 presents the spanwise distributions of β and |λ*| obtained in the design of FSW. A comparative analysis on the SS limiting streamlines of USW and FSW was reported in Vad [2]. In addition, the conical blade sections considered in the Q3D approach, corresponding to the β distribution in Fig. 6, are compared to the meridional projection of SS limiting streamlines of FSW in Fig. 7, reproduced from Corsini and Rispoli [35]. The fair agreement between the modelled conical sections and the SS limiting streamlines, especially away from the endwalls, supports the self-consistency of the Q3D design approach proposed by the author. Fig. 6
Spanwise distributions of β and |λ*| Fig. 7
Comparison between simulated SS limiting streamlines (solid lines extending from LE to TE) and conical sections modelled in the Q3D approach (dashed lines) for FSW. Notes: Contour lines: static pressure coefficient [35]

When manufacturing FSW, the 35° favourable sweep angle obtained near the hub (referring to Fig. 6) was applied along the entire span, as a reasonable approximation, for moderating the axial extension of the rotor.

Since this case study regards preliminary blade design, the FSW rotor presented herein is not meant to be the best solution available from this particular design assignment, in lack of an extensive, fully 3D CFD-based iterative refinement of rotor geometry, also incorporating the spanwise distribution of sweep. Still, as demonstrated in Fig. 8 (reproduced from Corsini and Rispoli [35]), FSW exhibits considerably lower total pressure loss along the dominant portion of span, especially on the SS and away from the endwalls – just in the region in which the presently proposed method aims at reducing the loss. Considering the studies in Vad [2], this is attributed to the design method presented herein. The local total pressure loss coefficient ωloc presented in Fig. 8 is defined in Corsini and Rispoli [35]. The paper of Corsini and Rispoli [41] reports on the difference between averaged total pressure loss coefficients related to FSW and USW in this case study. The data indicate that applying FSW, as designed by the author, resulted in total pressure loss reduction along the dominant part of span, especially away from the endwalls. The spanwise mean value of loss reduction is approximately 10 per cent of dynamic pressure calculated with inlet relative velocity at midspan [41]. Fig. 8
Evolution of total pressure loss coefficient ωloc inside the blade passages at 10% and 98% blade chord [35]

The FSW rotor was manufactured with larger tip clearance, for mechanical reasons (τ/SFSW = 0.04, τ/SUSW = 0.029). The characteristic and efficiency curves were measured for both USW and FSW [40], and were published later also in Corsini and Rispoli [35, 41]. The experimental uncertainties are reported in Table 2. Measured at the design flow rate, FSW generated a slightly higher total pressure rise: ΨFSW = 0.52, ΨUSW = 0.49 [35]. The global total efficiency measured for FSW has been corrected for the clearance size valid for the USW rotor, on the basis of the semi-empirical expression in Lakshminarayana [38], with substitution of near-tip data approximated using Fig. 5 (ψ∧2 = 0.65, ϕ∧12 = 0.5, α∞ = 50°) and AR = 0.597 from Table 1.

Due to the incorporation of FSW in the CVD method, the CFD and experiment-based data showed 2 per cent [35] and 3 per cent gain in η¯t, respectively, at the design flow rate. As the literature overview in Vad [7] suggests, efficiency gain in the per cent order of magnitude is considered as success in turbomachinery R&D. In this view, the preliminary design method proposed herein offers potential for efficiency gain that is worth mentioning.

sec.title: 6 SUMMARY
sec.p: A new preliminary CVD blade design method has been elaborated, incorporating FSW in CVD. Supplementing the traditional Q2D CVD technique, the new method enables a more accurate consideration and control of blade aerodynamics along the 3D SS flow paths, where the majority of loss is generated away from the endwalls. For this purpose, the new method unifies the Q2D and Q3D blade design approaches for CVD rotors. A key issue of the method is determining the favourable blade solidities separately in the Q2D and Q3D approaches, and realizing these different solidities in one FSW blade geometry. Modelling the blade passage flow via the Q3D approach is to be aided by CFD. The view dominates in literature that sweep is a design input, i.e. it is prescribed arbitrarily in preliminary design. In contrast, the new method serves with the sweep angle distribution as design output, i.e. the blade stacking geometry, found beneficial from aerodynamic point of view, is a result of the preliminary design process. The new method can rely on traditional 2D cascade correlations.

A design case study has been presented for demonstration of the capability of the proposed method. CFD data by Corsini and Rispoli [35], linked to the case study, supported the consistency and advantages of the proposed method, such as fair agreement between simulated and modelled 3D flow features and moderation of total pressure loss on the SS away from the endwalls. The case study revealed that the new method offers the potential for efficiency gain in the per cent order of magnitude at the design flow rate, considered as success in recent turbomachinery R&D.

The success of the design method incorporating FSW in CVD supports the latent tendency appearing in literature, e.g. references [10], [12], [22], [23], and [26], and pointed out by the author [7], that FSW is especially beneficial for efficiency gain in the case of CVD rotors, at the design point. In these cases, efficiency gain up to the per cent order of magnitude has been reported.

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: The study has been supported by the Hungarian National Fund for Science and Research under grant no. OTKA K 83807.

ack.title: ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
ack.p: The article relates to the scientific programme of the project ‘Development of quality-oriented and harmonized R+D+I strategy and the functional model at BME’. The New Széchenyi Plan (Project ID: TÁMOP-4.2.1/B-09/1/KMR-2010-0002) supports this project.

sec.title: APPENDIX 2
sec.p: The ratio of outlet and inlet relative velocities can be expressed as (21)

Therefore, justification of (22) implies the validity of relationship (17a). As suggested by Fig. 9, the change in tangential relative velocity through the cascade is (23) Fig. 9
Sketch for explanation of diffusion
A non-dimensional representation is applied further on. Equation (23) in non-dimensional form reads (23a)
For moderate flow deflection, as a brief approximation (see the figure) (24) is applied. Substituting equation (23) into equation (24), and considering (w∧1/utip)2=ϕ∧12 2+R1 2, yields (25)

In what follows, terms I to III marked in equation (25) are discussed. Term I
R1 Q3D < R1 Q2D (=R12). The axial velocity at the outlet increases with span, on the basis of equation (9), as far as ηt>ψ∧2/2R2 2, being valid for most applications. This means that ϕ∧2 Q3D>ϕ∧2 Q2D, since R2 Q3D>R2 Q2D(=R12). Furthermore, at the inlet, the axial velocity usually decreases with radius, due to streamline curvature affected by the inlet nose cone, e.g. Corsini and Rispoli [35]. This results in ϕ∧1 Q3D>ϕ∧1 Q2D, since R1 Q3D<R1 Q2D. As consequence of the aforementioned trends, ϕ∧12 Q3D>ϕ∧12 Q2D, considering equation (7a). R1Q3D < R1Q2D and ϕ∧12 Q3D>ϕ∧12 Q2D imply that Term I is smaller for the Q3D approach, supporting the trend in relationship (22). Term II
The ratio of this term for the Q3D and Q2D approaches can be written as follows, considering equation (10) (26a)
Here, it has been taken into account that ψ∧2(νht) and νht m are equal in design for the Q2D and Q3D approaches.
With substituting R1 Q3D=R12-ΔR and R2 Q3D=R12+ΔR, and considering that ΔR< <R12, it can be pointed out that R1 Q2D/R1 Q3D≈R2 Q3D/R2 Q2D. Therefore, equation (26a) can be written as (26b)

Since R2 Q3D/R2 Q2D>1, and m > 0 for CVD, this ratio is always positive, acting against the trend in equation (22). However, as pointed out in the example at the end of this Appendix, the trends related to Terms I and III, supporting trend (22), dominate. The trends related to Terms I to III, supporting or acting against trend (22), and eventually, the validity of relationship (17a), are to be analysed in each particular design assignment.

statement.title: Term III
statement.p: This term is zero in the Q2D approach (R1 Q2D = R2 Q2D = R12), and is negative in the Q3D approach (R2 Q3D > R1 Q3D), supporting trend (22).

statement.title: Design case study
statement.p:
For the design case study presented in Section 5, data summarized in Table 3 are characteristic in the region of midspan radius R12 = 0.838. The data demonstrate that the trends related to Terms I and III dominate. Table 3
